Welcome to appserver.io

appserver.io is a next generation PHP infrastructure. It is not a webserver like Apache or nginx, nor a Timer-Service or Message-Queue. It is all of them and much more in one extremely powerful bundle. And it is completely written in PHP enabling PHP developers to adapt appserver.io to their specific needs with no additional coding language - just PHP!

Basic Usage

The appserver will automatically start after your installation wizard (or package manager) finishes the setup. You can use it without limitations from now on.

Below you can find basic instructions on how to make use of the appserver. After the installation you might want to have a look and the bundled example application. The example application shows basic usage of services. Use your favorite browser and open the URL 

http://127.0.0.1:9080/example

You will see that we provide basic frontend implementations of services the appserver runtime provides. If you want to use these services yourself you should have a look into the sourcecode and read our tutorial about starting your own webapp.

You might be curious about the different port we use. Per default the appserver will open several ports at which it's services are available. As we do not want to block (or be blocked by) other services we use ports of a higher range.

As a default we use the following ports for the Web-Container:

  • HTTP-Server: 9080
  • HTTPS-Server: 9443

For the Persistence-Container we use:

  • Persistence-Container: 8585
  • Message-Queue: 8587

You can change this default port mapping by using the configuration file. If you are interested in our naming, you can see our Container-Server Pattern, you might want to have a deeper look into our architecture.

Services

Since appserver.io version 1.0.2 we provide and also install services during the installation process. This means, that you don't have to start or restart appserver.io after installation.

If you need to stop/start/restart the appserver.io, this can be done with the Windows Services which are available under Control Panel > System and Security > Administrative Tools > Services or the command line. When using Windows Services, simply select the service to be restarted, open the context menue and click on the restart entry.

Another option to start/stop a service is the commandline. Therefore open a commandline as Administrator and type 

net stop appserver
to stop the appserver service and 
net start appserver
to start it again. A more detailed documentation can be found in the Microsoft TechNet.

On a Windows system only the appserver and the appserver-php5-fpm services are functional actually. To ultimately run the appserver only the appserver process is needed but you will miss simple on-the-fly deployment (appserver-watcher) and might have problems with legacy applications. Depending on the FastCGI backend you want to use you might ditch appserver-php5-fpm for other processes e. g. supplying you with a HHVM backend.

Start and Stop Scripts

The second option, which is not the recommended one, to start/stop/restart services is to use the batch files, delivered with appserver.io.

  • appserver.bat: The main process which will start the appserver itself
  • appserver-php5-fpm.bat: PHP-FPM + appserver configuration. Our default FastCGI backend. Others might be added the same way
  • appserver-watcher.bat: A watchdog which monitors filesystem changes and manages appserver restarts
